events.description: The Nuragic civilization of Sardinia creates the Mont'e Prama statues ‚Äî monumental stone warriors standing over 2 meters tall. These are the oldest large-scale stone sculptures in the western Mediterranean after Egypt. The statues depict boxers, archers, and warriors with round shields. Buried and rediscovered in 1974, they remain among Sardinia's greatest archaeological treasures.
events.name: Mont'e Prama Giant Statues

events.description: The oldest known Phoenician inscription in the western Mediterranean, is erected at Nora in southern Sardinia. This stone monument marks the establishment of one of the earliest Phoenician trading posts on the island. Phoenician merchants from Tyre and Sidon trade peacefully with the Nuragic civilization, exchanging eastern goods for Sardinia's rich copper, lead, and silver resources.
events.name: Nora Stele

events.description: Phoenicians from Tyre establish Sulki (modern Sant'Antioco) ‚Äî likely the first Phoenician permanent settlement in Sardinia. The colony features a tophet sanctuary, necropolis, and port facilities. Sulki becomes a major hub for the Mediterranean metal trade, exporting Sardinian minerals to the eastern Mediterranean and importing luxury goods.
events.name: Foundation of Phoenician Sulki

events.description: Romulus founds Rome on Palatine Hill after killing his twin brother Remus in a dispute over where to build the city. According to legend, Romulus traced the city's sacred boundary (pomerium) with a plow, and Remus mocked him by jumping over it.
events.name: Legendary Founding of Rome

events.description: Romans abduct Sabine women during a festival to provide wives for the new city's male population. The act leads to war with the Sabines, ended when the abducted women intervened between their fathers and husbands on the battlefield.
events.name: Rape of the Sabine Women

events.description: Sabine king Titus Tatius becomes co-ruler of Rome with Romulus after peace is made following the women's intervention. The dual kingship establishes a precedent for shared power. Tatius is later killed during a religious festival at Lavinium.
events.name: Sabine-Roman Union

events.description: Romulus disappears during a sudden storm or eclipse while reviewing his troops at the Goat's Marsh (Caprae Palus). Some claimed he was torn apart by senators; officially, he ascended to heaven and became the god Quirinus.
events.name: Disappearance of Romulus

events.description: Numa Pompilius, a Sabine known for piety and wisdom, becomes Rome's second king after a year-long interregnum. He establishes the religious calendar, creates the Vestal Virgins, and builds the Temple of Janus ‚Äî its doors closed only in peacetime.
events.name: Reign of Numa Pompilius

events.description: Tullus Hostilius becomes the third king of Rome. Unlike peaceful Numa, he is warlike and seeks to expand Roman power. He considers Alba Longa, though Rome's mother city, a rival for leadership of the Latin peoples.
events.name: Tullus Hostilius Becomes King

events.description: Border raids between Rome and Alba Longa escalate as farmers steal cattle across boundaries. Both cities claim the other started the conflict. The Latin League watches as its two leading cities prepare for war over hegemony.
events.name: Rome-Alba Border Conflict

events.description: To avoid mass bloodshed between kinsmen, Rome and Alba Longa agree to decide the war by single combat. The Roman Horatii triplets fight the Alban Curiatii triplets. Two Horatii fall, but the survivor kills all three wounded Curiatii by feigning retreat and fighting them separately.
events.name: Combat of Horatii and Curiatii

events.description: Alba Longa accepts Roman supremacy after the Horatii victory, but Alban dictator Mettius Fufetius secretly plots with Fidenae and Veii against Rome. During a joint battle, he holds his troops back, waiting to see who wins before committing.
events.name: Alban Treachery at Fidenae

events.description: Tullus Hostilius punishes Mettius Fufetius for his treachery by having him torn apart by chariots driven in opposite directions ‚Äî the only case of this punishment in Roman history
events.name: Execution of Mettius Fufetius

events.description: King Tullus Hostilius destroys Alba Longa, Rome's mother city, after defeating it in war. Only the temples were not destroyed. The population is forcibly relocated to Rome, doubling the city's size.
events.name: Destruction of Alba Longa

events.description: Ancus Marcius, fourth king of Rome, founds the port of Ostia at the Tiber's mouth and builds the first bridge across the Tiber (Pons Sublicius). He expands Roman territory to the sea and settles conquered Latins on the Aventine Hill.
events.name: Foundation of Ostia

events.description: Lucius Tarquinius Priscus becomes the fifth king of Rome, the first of Etruscan origin. He drains the marshy valley between the hills to create the Forum Romanum and begins construction of the Temple of Jupiter on the Capitoline Hill.
events.name: Etruscan Kings Rule Rome

events.description: King Tarquinius Priscus establishes the Circus Maximus in the valley between the Palatine and Aventine hills. Initially a simple racetrack with wooden seating, it becomes Rome's principal venue for chariot racing and public spectacles, eventually holding 150,000 spectators.
events.name: Establishment of Circus Maximus

events.description: The Cloaca Maxima, one of the world's earliest sewage systems, is constructed to drain the marshy Forum valley. Originally an open channel, it is later covered over. Parts of this Etruscan-era drain remain in use today.
events.name: Construction of Cloaca Maxima

events.description: Servius Tullius, the sixth king, reforms Roman society by organizing citizens into classes based on wealth rather than birth. He builds the first defensive wall around all seven hills (Servian Wall) and establishes the census.
events.name: Servian Reforms

events.description: Phocaean Greeks fleeing Persian expansion in Asia Minor found the colony of Alalia (later Aleria) on Corsica's fertile east coast. They call the island 'Kalliste' (the most beautiful). The colony thrives on trade, agriculture, and piracy ‚Äî provoking both Etruscans and Carthaginians.
events.name: Foundation of Phocaean Alalia

events.description: The Carthaginian general Malchus leads a military expedition to conquer Sardinia, seeking to subjugate the Nuragic civilization living there. Carthage seizes control of the fertile plains of Campidano and the rich silver and iron mines of Iglesiente, gradually driving the local population into the mountains.
events.name: Carthaginian Conquest of Sardinia

events.description: 60 Phocaean Greek ships clash with 120 allied Etruscan-Carthaginian vessels off Corsica. The Greeks win tactically but lose 40 ships ‚Äî a Pyrrhic victory. The surviving Greeks abandon Corsica and flee to southern Italy. Corsica passes to Etruscan control, Sardinia remains Carthaginian. This battle marks the end of Greek expansion in the western Mediterranean.
events.name: Battle of Alalia

events.description: Servius Tullius is murdered by his own daughter Tullia and her husband Tarquinius Superbus (the Proud). Tullia drives her chariot over her father's body in the street later called Vicus Sceleratus (Street of Crime). Tarquinius becomes the seventh and last king.
events.name: Murder of Servius Tullius

events.description: The Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus is dedicated on the Capitoline Hill, becoming Rome's most important temple. The building was begun by the Tarquins but dedicated after their expulsion ‚Äî Romans refused to let kings take credit for it.
events.name: Temple of Jupiter Dedicated

events.description: Romans expel King Tarquinius Superbus after his son Sextus rapes the noblewoman Lucretia, who commits suicide after revealing the crime. Lucius Junius Brutus leads the revolt and becomes one of the first two consuls of the new Republic.
events.name: Founding of the Roman Republic

events.description: Lars Porsena of Clusium besieges Rome to restore Tarquinius. Horatius Cocles holds the Sublician Bridge alone against the Etruscan army while Romans destroy it behind him. He then swims to safety in full armor. Rome likely submitted but later rewrote history.
events.name: Horatius at the Bridge

events.description: Gaius Mucius Scaevola infiltrates Porsena's camp to assassinate him but kills the wrong man. Captured, he thrusts his right hand into a fire to show Roman contempt for pain and death. Impressed, Porsena makes peace. 'Scaevola' means 'left-handed.'
events.name: Mucius Scaevola

events.description: Expelled Tarquins seek help from the Etruscan city of Veii. Veii and other Etruscan cities see an opportunity to weaken Rome while it is adjusting to republican government. This begins centuries of Roman-Etruscan conflict.
events.name: Veii Supports Tarquins

events.description: The Temple of Saturn is dedicated in the Roman Forum, becoming one of Rome's oldest and most important temples. It housed the state treasury (aerarium) and the standards of the legions. The Saturnalia festival, celebrated each December, began here with a public sacrifice.
events.name: Temple of Saturn Dedicated

events.description: Romans defeat the Latin League at Lake Regillus. The divine twins Castor and Pollux allegedly appeared on white horses to lead the Roman cavalry. Their temple in the Forum, built to commemorate this, became a meeting place for the Senate.
events.name: Battle of Lake Regillus

events.description: Plebeians, burdened by debt and military service without political rights, withdraw from Rome to the Sacred Mount (Mons Sacer) in the first secession. They threaten to found a new city. Patricians negotiate, creating the office of Tribune of the Plebs with veto power.
events.name: First Plebeian Secession

events.description: Rome signs the Foedus Cassianum (Treaty of Cassius) with the Latin League, establishing equal alliance. Latin and Roman forces will alternate command and share spoils equally. This treaty governs Roman-Latin relations for 150 years.
events.name: Rome signs treaty with the Latins

events.description: Coriolanus, a patrician hero who opposed grain distribution to plebeians, is exiled and joins the Volscians. He leads them to Rome's gates but turns back when his mother Veturia and wife Volumnia plead with him. The Volscians later kill him as a traitor.
events.name: Coriolanus and the Volscians

events.description: Consul Spurius Cassius proposes the first agrarian law (lex agraria) to distribute public land to plebeians and Latin allies. Patricians accuse him of seeking tyranny; he is executed the following year ‚Äî the first in a pattern of reformers meeting violent ends.
events.name: First Agrarian Law Proposed

events.description: Veii launches raids into Roman territory from its fortress at Fidenae, only 8 km from Rome. Fidenae controls a key Tiber crossing and threatens Roman trade. For decades, Veii and Rome fight an on-and-off war over this strategic point.
events.name: War Over Fidenae Begins

events.description: The Temple of Castor and Pollux is dedicated in the Roman Forum to commemorate the Battle of Lake Regillus (496 BC), where the divine twins allegedly appeared to help the Romans defeat the Latin League. The temple becomes a meeting place for the Senate and a landmark of the Forum.
events.name: Temple of Castor and Pollux Dedicated

events.description: The entire Fabii clan (306 men and their clients) takes responsibility for guarding the Veii frontier. They are ambushed at the Cremera River and wiped out to the last man. Only one Fabius boy, left in Rome due to youth, survives to continue the family.
events.name: Disaster at the Cremera

events.description: Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus, a farmer, is called from his plow to serve as dictator when Rome faces military crisis. He defeats the Aequi in 16 days, celebrates a triumph, and immediately resigns his absolute power to return to farming ‚Äî becoming the Roman ideal of civic virtue.
events.name: Cincinnatus Called from the Plow

events.description: The Twelve Tables, Rome's first written law code, are created by a commission of ten men (decemviri). Displayed in the Forum, these bronze tablets codify customary law and end patrician monopoly on legal knowledge. Schoolchildren memorized them for centuries.
events.name: Twelve Tables of Roman Law

events.description: The tyrannical decemvir Appius Claudius attempts to enslave the plebeian virgin Virginia through a fraudulent legal claim. Her father Virginius kills her in the Forum to preserve her honor. The scandal triggers the second plebeian secession and fall of the decemvirate.
events.name: Death of Virginia

events.description: The Lex Canuleia legalizes marriage between patricians and plebeians, previously forbidden. Tribune Gaius Canuleius argued that without intermarriage, Rome was not one people but two. The law begins the slow fusion of the orders.
events.name: Lex Canuleia

events.description: Fidenae revolts against Rome and kills Roman ambassadors ‚Äî a grave violation of ancient law. Lars Tolumnius, king of Veii, is blamed for ordering the murders. Rome declares war to avenge this outrage.
events.name: Murder of Roman Ambassadors at Fidenae

events.description: Aulus Cornelius Cossus kills Lars Tolumnius in single combat and takes his armor as spolia opima ‚Äî the supreme military honor, awarded only three times in Roman history for killing an enemy king in personal combat.
events.name: Death of Etruscan king in combat

events.description: Rome finally captures and destroys Fidenae, eliminating the threat to the Tiber crossing. This clears the way for direct war with Veii itself. The stage is set for Rome's first great siege.
events.name: Destruction of Fidenae

events.description: Rome begins paying soldiers a stipend (stipendium), allowing extended campaigns without soldiers returning for harvest. Previously, war was seasonal because citizen-farmers needed to work their land. This professionalizes warfare and enables the long siege of Veii.
events.name: Soldiers Begin Receiving Pay

events.description: Rome begins the siege of Veii itself ‚Äî a city as large and wealthy as Rome. Other Etruscan cities, distracted by Gallic raids in the north, fail to send help. The siege will last ten years, like legendary Troy.
events.name: Siege of Veii Begins

events.description: Gallic Senones tribe crosses the Alps and settles in the ager Gallicus along the Adriatic coast. They pressure Etruscan cities, which diverts Etruscan attention from Rome and leaves Veii isolated during its siege.
events.name: Gauls Settle in Italy

events.description: After a ten-year siege, Marcus Furius Camillus captures the wealthy Etruscan city of Veii, 16 km north of Rome. He reportedly dug a tunnel into the citadel. Veii's territory doubles Roman land, and its population is enslaved or absorbed.
events.name: Fall of Veii

events.description: Gauls besiege Clusium, an Etruscan city that appeals to Rome for help. Rome sends ambassadors to negotiate, but they violate neutrality by fighting alongside Clusians. When Rome refuses to hand them over, Brennus leads his army toward Rome.
events.name: Gallic Siege of Clusium

events.description: Gallic Senones under Brennus defeat the Roman army at the Allia River and sack Rome. Only the Capitoline Hill holds out, reportedly saved when sacred geese alert defenders to a night attack. Romans pay 1,000 pounds of gold as ransom. When Romans complain about rigged scales, Brennus throws his sword on them saying 'Vae victis!' (Woe to the vanquished!).
events.name: Gallic Sack of Rome

events.description: Camillus, recalled from exile, defeats the Gauls at Tusculum and drives them from Roman territory. Declared 'Second Founder of Rome,' he oversees the city's rebuilding. When some propose moving to Veii, he convinces Romans to rebuild on the original site.
events.name: Camillus Saves Rome

events.description: The Servian Wall is rebuilt after the Gallic sack, encircling all seven hills of Rome with tufa blocks. At 11 km long and up to 10 m high, it remains Rome's main defensive wall for centuries. Parts still stand today near Termini station.
events.name: Servian Wall Rebuilt

events.description: The Licinian-Sextian laws end patrician monopoly on the consulship, requiring one consul to be plebeian. They also limit individual holdings of public land to 500 iugera (125 hectares) and regulate debt. This marks a major victory in the Conflict of the Orders.
events.name: Licinian-Sextian Laws

events.description: The first plebeian consul, Lucius Sextius Lateranus, takes office ‚Äî a watershed moment after 143 years of patrician monopoly. The office of praetor is created to handle judicial duties formerly performed by consuls.
events.name: First Plebeian Consul

events.description: Latin allies grow resentful as Rome increasingly dominates the alliance, taking the best land from conquered territories and treating allies as subordinates rather than equals. Tensions rise within the Latin League.
events.name: Latin Resentment Grows

events.description: Rome signs a treaty with the Samnites, a powerful confederation of Oscan-speaking tribes controlling the central Apennines. The treaty divides spheres of influence in central Italy ‚Äî an arrangement that would break down within a decade.
events.name: Roman-Samnite Treaty

events.description: Rome institutionalizes rigorous military training that transforms citizen soldiers into disciplined professionals. Recruits drill with weighted practice weapons, march 20 Roman miles in 5 hours, and practice formation maneuvers until they become second nature. Centurions enforce iron discipline with the vitis (vine stick), used as a whip
events.name: Roman Military Training

events.description: Rome intervenes when Samnites attack Capua and other Campanian cities that appeal for Roman protection. The First Samnite War begins Rome's long struggle for control of central and southern Italy against the Samnite confederacy.
events.name: First Samnite War Begins

events.description: Latins and Campanians demand full Roman citizenship and half the Senate seats, or they will secede. Rome refuses. The Latins ally with Volscians, Aurunci, and Sidicini. The Latin War begins ‚Äî a war to determine whether Rome or the League will lead Italy.
events.name: Latin Ultimatum to Rome

events.description: Rome's Latin allies revolt against Roman hegemony in the Latin War. According to tradition, consul Publius Decius Mus performs devotio ‚Äî ritually sacrificing himself to the gods in battle to ensure Roman victory. The war ends with dissolution of the Latin League and integration of Latins into Roman citizenship.
events.name: Latin War

events.description: At Mount Vesuvius, consul Titus Manlius Torquatus executes his own son for disobeying orders by engaging in single combat with a Latin champion ‚Äî though victorious. "Manlian discipline" becomes proverbial for severity.
events.name: Manlian Discipline

events.description: Rome dissolves the Latin League after victory, replacing it with individual treaties. Some Latins receive full citizenship, others partial rights, creating a graded system of relationships that becomes a model for Roman expansion.
events.name: Roman Settlement of Latium

events.description: Naples (Neapolis), a Greek city allied with the Samnites, insults Roman envoys. Rome besieges the city, which the Samnites try to relieve. This begins the Second Samnite War ‚Äî 22 years of brutal mountain warfare.
events.name: Second Samnite War Begins

events.description: The Lex Poetelia abolishes debt bondage (nexum), the practice of selling oneself or family into slavery to pay debts. This reform follows the case of a young debtor sexually abused by his creditor, sparking public outrage.
events.name: Abolition of Debt Bondage

events.description: Romans suffer their worst humiliation when an army is trapped in the Caudine Forks mountain pass by Samnites under Gaius Pontius. Unable to fight or escape, the entire army is forced to pass under the yoke (sub iugum) ‚Äî a gateway of spears symbolizing utter defeat. The peace treaty is later repudiated by Rome.
events.name: Disaster at Caudine Forks

events.description: After the Caudine Forks disaster, Rome repudiates the peace treaty, claiming the consuls had no authority to make it. The Senate hands over the consuls naked and bound to the Samnites, who refuse them. War resumes with Roman fury for revenge.
events.name: Rome Repudiates Caudine Peace

events.description: An impregnable fortress on a tuff rock, to protect Campania and the mountain gorges from Samnite raids. Originally inhabited by the Caudini tribe, Rome managed to capture the settlement. The capture of Saticula became Roman "revenge" for the defeats of the first years of the war.
events.name: Roman fortress of Saticula

events.description: Rome adopted the manipular legion during the Samnite Wars. The new system divided the infantry into three lines: hastati (young men), principes (experienced men), and triarii (veterans). The hastati enter the battle first, the principes cover them, and in extreme cases the triarii enter the battle. The new system provides significantly greater mobility than the Greek phalanx and allows to make sustained, firm pressure on the enemy.
events.name: Manipular Legion System

events.description: Romans suffer another major defeat at Lautulae near Terracina. Samnites raid Latin territory and nearly reach Rome. Rome responds by building a network of fortified colonies and roads through the mountains to control territory permanently.
events.name: Battle of Lautulae

events.description: Rome adopts the pilum, a heavy javelin with a unique design: a long iron shank that bends on impact, preventing enemies from throwing it back and rendering shields unusable. Each legionary carries two pila, throwing them at 15-30 meters before closing with gladius. The weapon disrupts enemy formations before melee.
events.name: Adoption of the Pilum by Romans

events.description: Rome, taking advantage of its developing infrastructure, surrounded Samnium with its fortresses to cut off the Samnites from external communications and overwhelm them with numbers. Luceria blocked the Samnites' access to the fertile plains of Apulia, from where they obtained grain and livestock.
events.name: The Roman fortress of Luceria

events.description: Appius Claudius also builds Rome's first aqueduct, the Aqua Appia, bringing fresh water 16 km from springs in the Sabine hills. Running mostly underground, it delivers 73,000 cubic meters of water daily to the growing city.
events.name: First Roman Aqueduct

events.description: Censor Appius Claudius Caecus begins construction of the Via Appia, Rome's first major paved road, connecting Rome to Capua (later extended to Brindisi). 'Regina viarum' (Queen of Roads), it enables rapid military movement and trade, becoming the model for all Roman roads.
events.name: Construction of Via Appia

events.description: Roman consul Quintus Fabius Maximus Rullianus leads an army through the Ciminian Forest, a dense woodland considered impassable. Emerging behind Etruscan lines, he wins a decisive victory. This bold move opens northern Etruria to Roman conquest.
events.name: Passage of Ciminian Forest

events.description: After defeats, the Samnites seek peace. Rome demands territory, hostages, and restrictions on Samnite foreign policy. The humiliating terms ensure that war will resume when Samnites recover their strength.
events.name: End of Second Samnite War

events.description: Gnaeus Flavius, a secretary, publishes the legis actiones (legal procedures) and the calendar showing court days ‚Äî information previously monopolized by patrician pontiffs. This 'theft' of priestly knowledge enrages nobles but empowers ordinary citizens.
events.name: Publication of Legal Procedures

events.description: Rome develops standardized road construction techniques that will endure for millennia: multi-layered foundation of mortar, stones, and gravel; cambered surface for drainage; drainage ditches with retaining walls; cuttings through hills rather than detours. Roman engineers prefer straight paths, building bridges and tunnels rather than avoiding obstacles. Many Roman roads remain in use today.
events.name: Roman Road Engineering Standards

events.description: The Third Samnite War begins as Samnites form a grand coalition with Gauls, Etruscans, and Umbrians against Rome. This 'war of Italian liberation' represents the last major attempt to check Roman expansion in the peninsula.
events.name: Third Samnite War Begins

events.description: At Sentinum, Rome faces a coalition of Samnites, Gauls, Etruscans and Umbrians ‚Äî the largest army Italy ever assembled against Rome. Consul Publius Decius Mus (son of the earlier Decius) performs devotio like his father. Romans win decisively, breaking Samnite power and securing central Italy.
events.name: Battle of Sentinum

events.description: At Aquilonia, Romans storm the Samnite sacred enclosure where their elite "Linen Legion" has sworn to fight to the death. 20,000 Samnites die. This breaks the military power of the Samnite confederacy forever.
events.name: Battle of Aquilonia

events.description: Manius Curius Dentatus conquers the Sabines and celebrates a triumph. He famously refuses bribes, saying he would rather rule those who have gold than have it himself. Sabine territory is incorporated, and many Sabines receive citizenship.
events.name: Conquest of the Sabines

events.description: The Lex Hortensia makes plebiscites (decisions of the plebeian assembly) binding on all citizens including patricians, without Senate approval. This completes the Conflict of the Orders, establishing legal equality between patricians and plebeians after two centuries of struggle.
events.name: Lex Hortensia

events.description: Romans defeat the Senones Gauls at Lake Vadimo in Etruria, then systematically expel the entire tribe from Italy. The Senones are the same Gauls who sacked Rome in 390 BC. Their territory becomes the ager Gallicus, settled by Roman colonists.
events.name: Battle of Lake Vadimo

events.description: After Heraclea, Pyrrhus sends his advisor Cineas to Rome to negotiate peace. Despite Cineas's famous eloquence, the blind old senator Appius Claudius Caecus rallies the Senate to refuse ‚Äî Rome's first clear statement that it would never negotiate after defeat.
events.name: Cineas Mission to Rome

events.description: King Pyrrhus of Epirus lands in Italy with 25,000 soldiers and 20 war elephants to aid Tarentum in its fight against Rome. At Heraclea, his elephants ('Lucanian bulls') frighten the Roman horses. This was a resounding victory for Pyrrhus, opening the way for him to go deeper into Italy.
events.name: Pyrrhus defeats the Romans at Heraclea

events.description: Rome standardizes the castra ‚Äî fortified military camp built every night during march. Following rigid engineering specifications, legionaries construct ramparts, ditches, gates, and internal grid layout in hours. This discipline provides security, intimidates enemies, and demonstrates Roman organizational superiority. Each soldier knows exactly where to position his tent. The castrum turns the Roman army into a walking fortress.
events.name: Roman Military Camp (Castra)

events.description: Pyrrhus defeats Romans again at Asculum but loses 3,500 of his best troops, including many officers. When congratulated, he reportedly responds: 'If we win one more such battle against the Romans, we shall be utterly ruined.'
events.name: Pyrrhus defeats the Romans at Asculum

events.description: Romans finally defeat Pyrrhus at Beneventum using tactics developed to counter war elephants ‚Äî stampeding them back into their own lines with fire and javelins. Unable to replace losses far from home, he eventually abandons Italy.
events.name: Rome defeats Pyrrhus at Beneventum

events.description: Roman builders develop opus caementicium (Roman concrete) by mixing volcanic ash (pozzolana) with lime and aggregate. First used at the colony of Cosa, this revolutionary material allows construction of unprecedented structures. Unlike modern concrete, Roman concrete actually strengthens over centuries through mineral crystallization.
events.name: Invention of Roman Concrete

events.description: Rome's second aqueduct, the Aqua Anio Vetus, is constructed using war spoils from the victory over Pyrrhus. Drawing water from the upper Anio River near Tivoli, its 64 km mostly underground channel doubles Rome's water supply. The name 'Vetus' (old) distinguishes it from the later Aqua Anio Novus.
events.name: Aqua Anio Vetus Aqueduct

events.description: Tarentum surrenders to Rome after Pyrrhus's final departure. Rome now controls all of peninsular Italy south of the Po Valley. Greek cities retain local autonomy but become Roman allies, beginning Rome's absorption of Magna Graecia and Greek cultural influence.
events.name: Fall of Tarentum

events.description: Rome mints its first silver coinage, the denarius, as contact with Greek civilization demands participation in Mediterranean trade. Previously, Romans used bronze by weight. The new coinage facilitates commerce and soldiers' pay.
events.name: First Roman Silver Coinage

events.description: Rome founds a colony at Firmum (Fermo) on the Adriatic coast, part of a systematic colonization program. Roman and Latin colonies serve as garrison towns, spreading Roman influence, relieving population pressure, and providing land for veterans.
events.name: Colony of Rome in Fermo

events.description: Facing the superior Carthaginian navy in the First Punic War, Rome invents the corvus ('raven') ‚Äî a rotating boarding bridge with a heavy spike that drops onto enemy decks, locking ships together. This ingenious device transforms naval warfare into land battle, where Roman legionaries excel
events.name: Invention of the Corvus

events.description: Consul Lucius Cornelius Scipio leads a naval expedition to Corsica and captures the key city of Aleria on the east coast. His tomb inscription proudly records: 'He took Corsica and the city of Aleria.' This is Rome's first territorial expansion beyond Sicily. However, the island's fierce mountain tribes will resist Roman rule for nearly a century more.
events.name: Roman Capture of Aleria

events.description: The testudo ('tortoise') formation becomes a refined Roman tactic for siege operations. Soldiers interlock their large scuta shields to form a protective shell ‚Äî front rank vertical, inner ranks overhead like roof tiles. This 'human tank' allows troops to advance under heavy missile fire toward fortifications. The formation requires exceptional discipline and drilling.
events.name: Testudo Formation Tactics

events.description: Roman engineers develop sophisticated surveying instruments: the groma for laying out perpendicular lines and right angles; the chorobates for leveling; the dioptra for measuring angles. These tools enable precise gradient control for aqueducts (achieving 1:4800 slope over 50 km) and straight road construction. Roman precision surveying won't be surpassed until modern times.
events.name: Roman Surveying Instruments

events.description: The Via Aurelia is constructed along the Tyrrhenian coast from Rome to Pisae (Pisa), opening the northwestern route to Etruria and Liguria. Later extended to Genua (Genoa) and into Gaul, it becomes a vital artery for trade and military movement along Italy's western coast.
events.name: Construction of Via Aurelia

events.description: Carthaginian mercenaries stationed in Sardinia revolt over unpaid wages. Mercenaries seize control of Punic cities and kill Carthaginian commanders. Unable to hold the island, they turn to Rome for protection. This rebellion creates a political opportunity for Rome
events.name: Mercenary Revolt in Sardinia

events.description: Livius Andronicus, a Greek freedman from Tarentum, produces the first Latin tragedy and comedy adapted from Greek originals, performed at the Roman Games. This marks the birth of Latin literature and Rome's cultural transformation through Greek influence.
events.name: Birth of Latin Literature

events.description: While Carthage was suppressing a mercenary rebellion on its own soil, Rome presented Carthage with an ultimatum: surrender Sardinia and Corsica, and pay an additional 1,200 talents. The historian Polybius called this seizure "contrary to all justice." This humiliation and the unjust seizure of Sardinia forced Hamilcar Barca to swear eternal hatred against Rome and prepare his son Hannibal for a new war.
events.name: Roman Annexation of Sardinia and Corsica

events.description: The indigenous tribes rise up in armed resistance, calling on Carthage for help. Consul Titus Manlius Torquatus decisively suppresses the rebellion and celebrates a triumph in Rome. In Rome that year, for the first time since the time of King Numa Pompilius, the doors of the Temple of Janus were solemnly closed, which symbolized complete peace throughout the state.
events.name: Sardinian Revolt Against Rome

events.description: Gnaeus Naevius writes the first Latin epic, Bellum Punicum (Punic War), based on recent history rather than Greek myth. He later satirizes the Metelli, a powerful family, and is imprisoned ‚Äî establishing the dangerous relationship between Roman writers and nobility.
events.name: First Latin Epic

events.description: Corsican mountain tribes rise against Roman rule. Consul Gaius Papirius Maso leads a punitive expedition into the island's interior to crush the resistance. After fierce fighting in the difficult mountainous terrain, he suppresses the revolt and receives the first-ever triumph celebrated on the Alban Mount (mons Albanus) ‚Äî a lesser form of triumph, reflecting the modest scale of the victory.
events.name: Corsica revolts against Rome

events.description: Rome formally organizes Sardinia and Corsica into the province of Sardinia et Corsica, governed by a dedicated praetor based in Caralis (Cagliari). The islands become Rome's second overseas province after Sicily, serving as a critical grain supply and strategic naval base protecting Italy's western approaches.
events.name: Province of Sardinia et Corsica Established

events.description: A massive Celtic invasion from the Po Valley is crushed at Telamon in Etruria, where Romans trap the Gauls between two armies. This decisive victory leads to Roman conquest of Cisalpine Gaul (northern Italy) and the founding of colonies at Placentia and Cremona.
events.name: Battle of Telamon

events.description: Rome conquers the Celtic settlement of Medelanon and names it Mediolanum. It becomes an important strategic point for Rome in the Po Valley.
events.name: Rome captures Medelanon

events.description: Censor Gaius Flaminius builds the Via Flaminia from Rome to Ariminum (Rimini) on the Adriatic coast, opening northern Italy to Roman colonization. He is controversial for bypassing the Senate and championing popular causes against aristocratic interests.
events.name: Construction of Via Flaminia

events.description: Rome founds colonies at Placentia (Piacenza) and Cremona in the Po Valley to control recently conquered Cisalpine Gaul. These fortified cities will soon prove critical during Hannibal's invasion, remaining loyal despite being surrounded by hostile territory.
events.name: Foundation of Placentia and Cremona

events.description: After Hannibal's victory at Cannae, Sardinian leader Hampsicora unites native tribes and Punic coastal cities in revolt against Rome. Carthage sends 15,000 troops under Hasdrubal the Bald. Praetor Titus Manlius Torquatus crushes the combined forces near Cornus in a 4-hour battle. Hasdrubal is captured; Hampsicora, learning of his son Hiostus's death, commits suicide
events.name: Battle of Cornus

events.description: The Great Mother (Cybele), a black meteorite from Phrygia, was brought to Rome because a prophecy declared it essential for defeating Hannibal. The Romans persuaded the King of Pergamon to hand over the relic, citing their affiliation with Troy and its deities. The cult of a foreign goddess with her eunuch priests and ecstatic rituals disturbs the Romans, but becomes officially Roman.
events.name: Magna Mater Comes to Rome

events.description: After encountering Celtiberian swords during the Punic Wars, Rome adopts the gladius Hispaniensis as standard legionary weapon. This short, double-edged sword (45-65 cm blade) excels at both thrusting and cutting in tight formations. Combined with the large scutum shield, it makes the Roman legionary the deadliest close-combat soldier in the ancient world.
events.name: Adoption of the Gladius Hispaniensis

events.description: Romans master the structural arch, perfecting the voussoir (wedge-shaped stones) with keystone technique. Unlike post-and-lintel construction, arches distribute weight outward, enabling unprecedented spans for bridges, aqueducts, and buildings. Combined with Roman concrete, arch technology enables the construction of structures that will stand for millennia.
events.name: Mastery of Roman Arch

events.description: Philip V sought to establish complete control over the straits (the Hellespont) to cut off his enemies‚ÄîPergamon and Rhodes‚Äîfrom Black Sea trade. Abydos was a key port, blocking the entrance to the strait. Its capture would deprive hostile fleets of a base for operations against Macedonia. The city resisted fiercely, and almost no one surrendered.
events.name: Macedonia besieges and ravages Abydos

events.description: Quintus Fabius Pictor writes the first history of Rome in Greek, aimed at explaining Rome to the Greek world after the Second Punic War. His lost work established the traditional founding date of 753 BC and shaped all later Roman historiography.
events.name: First Roman History Written

events.description: At Cynoscephalae in Thessaly, Roman legions under Flamininus defeat the Macedonian phalanx of Philip V. The flexible Roman maniple system proves superior to the rigid phalanx on broken ground. This ends the Second Macedonian War and establishes Rome as arbiter of Greek affairs.
events.name: Battle of Cynoscephalae

events.description: At the Isthmian Games, Flamininus proclaims freedom for all Greeks from Macedonian control. Greeks erupt in such joyful shouting that birds reportedly fall from the sky. Rome positions itself as liberator, though 'freedom' means freedom to be Roman clients.
events.name: Freedom of the Greeks Proclaimed

events.description: Consul Marcus Aemilius Lepidus constructs the Via Aemilia from Ariminum (Rimini) to Placentia (Piacenza), crossing the fertile Po Valley. This 270 km road connects with the Via Flaminia, creating a continuous route from Rome to the Alpine frontier. The region takes its modern name, Emilia-Romagna, from this road.
events.name: Construction of Via Aemilia

events.description: The Senate suppresses the cult of Bacchus (Dionysus) throughout Italy after alleged crimes including murder and conspiracy. 7,000 people are reportedly executed. This Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus is the earliest Roman decree regulating religion.
events.name: Suppression of the Bacchanalia

events.description: Marcus Porcius Cato becomes censor and launches a moral crusade against luxury, Greek influence, and corruption. He expels senators, increases taxes on luxuries, and demolishes buildings encroaching on public land. His stern traditionalism becomes legendary.
events.name: Cato the Elder's Censorship

events.description: Construction begins on the Pons Aemilius, Rome's first stone bridge over the Tiber, replacing an earlier wooden structure. Completed in 142 BC, its innovative concrete core with stone facing set the model for Roman bridge engineering. Today only one arch survives, known as 'Ponte Rotto' (Broken Bridge).
events.name: Pons Aemilius - First Stone Bridge

events.description: Censors Marcus Aemilius Lepidus and Marcus Fulvius Nobilior build the Basilica Aemilia (Basilica Fulvia) in the Roman Forum. This large public hall serves as a law court, commercial center, and meeting place. Its marble floor, colonnades, and shops set the standard for Roman civic architecture.
events.name: Basilica Aemilia Built

events.description: Consul Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus leads two legions in a brutal two-year campaign against the Ilienses and Balari tribes in Sardinia's mountainous interior. According to Livy, 80,000 Sardinians are killed or enslaved, with captives sold so cheaply they create the proverb 'Sardi venales' (Sardinians for sale). Despite the devastation, the Barbagia highlands tribes are never fully subjugated
events.name: Gracchus's Sardinian Pacification

events.description: The Senate receives unprecedented complaints from allied cities about Roman magistrates' abuses in Spain. A tribunal is established, but the guilty praetors escape punishment through influence. This foreshadows later provincial exploitation.
events.name: First Provincial Abuse Trials

events.description: At Pydna, Roman consul Aemilius Paullus annihilates the Macedonian phalanx of King Perseus in under an hour. 20,000 Macedonians die. Perseus is paraded in Paullus's triumph and dies a Roman prisoner. Macedonia is divided into four puppet republics.
events.name: Battle of Pydna

events.description: Rome abolishes the tributum, direct tax on Roman citizens, paid for by the wealth flowing from conquered territories and provinces. Citizens would not pay direct taxes again until the crisis of the Empire three centuries later.
events.name: Direct Citizen Tax Abolished

events.description: Following their victory over Macedonia, the Romans transferred the island of Delos to Athenian control and declared it a tax-free zone (atelia). All merchants from Phoenicia, Egypt, and Italy, who had previously paid tolls at the Rhodes harbor, immediately transferred their ships to Delos.
events.name: Delos is a tax-free port

events.description: Rome's opening of the tax-free port of Delos crippled the economy of Rhodes, reducing trade revenues severalfold. Rhodes became impoverished; furthermore, Rome deprived Rhodes of its mainland holdings. Deprived of money and its navy, Rhodes ceased to function as the Mediterranean's police force, leading to the rise of Cilician piracy.
events.name: Economic blockade of Rhodes by Rome

events.description: Three Greek philosophers ‚Äî Carneades (skeptic), Diogenes (stoic), and Critolaus (peripatetic) ‚Äî come to Rome as Athenian ambassadors. Carneades shocks Romans by arguing both sides of justice on successive days, demonstrating rhetoric's power to prove anything.
events.name: Greek Philosophers in Rome

events.description: Rome perfects the ballista, a powerful two-armed torsion catapult capable of launching heavy bolts or stones over 300 meters. Roman improvements include metal reinforcement, better materials, and standardized production. By the 1st century AD, every century will have its own ballista, making Roman siege warfare unmatched.
events.name: Roman Ballista Artillery

events.description: The Lex Calpurnia establishes Rome's first permanent court (quaestio perpetua) to try provincial extortion cases. Previously, each case required special legislation. This begins the system of permanent specialized courts that would later try treason and murder.
events.name: First Permanent Court Established

events.description: Consul Spurius Postumius Albinus Magnus constructs the Via Postumia from Genua (Genoa) to Aquileia, crossing northern Italy from the Tyrrhenian to the Adriatic coast. This 530 km strategic highway connects the western and eastern frontiers, passing through Placentia, Cremona, and Verona.
events.name: Construction of Via Postumia

events.description: After defeating Macedonia, Rome demands that the Achaean League must be left by strongest Greek cities (Sparta, Corinth, Argos). The Greeks refuse, claiming this would clearly lead to the disintegration of the league and the fall of Greece. The brief and hopeless Achaean War begins between Rome and the league. Rome wins, and as a warning, the Roman commander Mummius destroys Corinth, killing the men and selling the women and children into slavery. The city remains uninhabited for a century.
events.name: Destruction of Corinth

events.description: Praetor Quintus Marcius Rex begins construction of the Aqua Marcia, Rome's longest and finest aqueduct. Drawing exceptionally pure water from springs near Arsoli in the Anio Valley, its 91 km channel includes spectacular above-ground arcades. The water was so prized that it was reserved for drinking.
events.name: Aqua Marcia Aqueduct

events.description: The Lex Gabinia introduces secret ballot for elections, followed by laws extending it to trials and legislation. Previously, voting was public and subject to intimidation. Conservative senators oppose this shield against aristocratic pressure.
events.name: Introduction of Secret Ballot

events.description: The First Servile War erupts in Sicily when mistreated slaves revolt under the Syrian Eunus, who proclaims himself King Antiochus. At its height, 200,000 slaves control most of Sicily. It takes Rome years and multiple armies to suppress.
events.name: First Servile War in Sicily

events.description: Tribune Tiberius Gracchus proposed seizing the wealthy's sprawling estates and dividing them up, distributing the lands among landless Romans. To push through the law, he even removed another tribune who had vetoed it - an unthinkable move in Roman politics. Tiberius generally interpreted the laws his own way, resulting in him and his supporters being beaten to death with bench legs.
events.name: Reforms and Death of Tiberius Gracchus

events.description: Censors Gnaeus Servilius Caepio and Lucius Cassius Longinus Ravilla build the Aqua Tepula, drawing lukewarm water (hence 'tepula') from springs in the Alban Hills near Marino. The 18 km aqueduct shares conduits with the later Aqua Julia, its waters mixed to improve temperature.
events.name: Aqua Tepula Aqueduct

events.description: Gaius Gracchus, brother of Tiberius, becomes tribune and enacts sweeping reforms: subsidized grain for Romans, jury reform to break senatorial corruption, road building, and colonial foundations. After two terms, he is declared a public enemy and killed with 3,000 supporters.
events.name: Reforms and Death of Gaius Gracchus

events.description: Quintus Caecilius Metellus conquered the island, exterminating the pirates. The cities of Palma and Pollentia (modern Alcudia) were founded. The Romans brought olives and grapes to the island and gradually replaced the Talaiotic culture that originally existed on the island.
events.name: The capture of Mallorca by Rome

events.description: The Senate passes the first senatus consultum ultimum (final decree), authorizing the consul to take any measures to protect the state ‚Äî effectively martial law. It is used to justify killing Gaius Gracchus and his followers without trial.
events.name: First Senatus Consultum Ultimum

events.description: The Temple of Hercules Victor is erected at the Forum Boarium, the oldest surviving marble building in Rome. Its circular design with 20 Corinthian columns shows strong Greek influence. Dedicated to Hercules, patron of merchants and olive oil traders, it stands near the ancient cattle market.
events.name: Temple of Hercules Victor

events.description: Rome founds Narbo Martius (Narbonne), its first colony outside Italy, in southern Gaul. This establishes permanent Roman presence across the Alps and begins the Romanization of Gaul. The area becomes the province of Gallia Narbonensis.
events.name: First Colony Outside Italy

events.description: Jugurtha, king of Numidia, massacres Italian merchants at Cirta while fighting for his throne. When Roman envoys come to investigate, he bribes them. His reported boast that 'Rome is a city for sale' humiliates the Senate and triggers war.
events.name: Jugurthine War Begins

events.description: Gaius Marius, a 'new man' without noble ancestry, is elected consul to end the Jugurthine War. He abolishes the property requirement for military service, opening the army to the landless poor. Soldiers now depend on their general for land grants after service ‚Äî fateful for the Republic.
events.name: Marian Military Reforms

events.description: Germanic tribes ‚Äî Cimbri and Teutones ‚Äî annihilate two Roman armies at Arausio (Orange) in southern Gaul. 80,000 Romans and 40,000 camp followers perish ‚Äî the worst defeat since Cannae. Marius is elected consul five times consecutively to meet the threat.
events.name: Disaster at Arausio

events.description: Marius destroys the Teutones at Aquae Sextiae (Aix-en-Provence). 100,000 are killed or captured. The Teuton women, refusing enslavement, kill their children and themselves. The following year, Marius destroys the Cimbri at Vercellae in northern Italy.
events.name: Marius Defeats the Cimbri and Teutones

events.description: The scorpio becomes a standard Roman precision weapon ‚Äî a smaller ballista operated by 1-2 men, accurate at 100 meters and deadly at 400 meters parabolic fire. Each legion deploys 60 scorpiones, one per century. Caesar praises its 'terrifying precision' at the siege of Avaricum. It serves as ancient Rome's 'sniper rifle.'
events.name: Scorpio Precision Artillery

events.description: Tribune Saturninus proposes radical land reforms for Marius's veterans, using violence to pass legislation. When Saturninus murders a political rival, Marius reluctantly enforces the senatus consultum ultimum against his own ally, who is killed by a mob.
events.name: Violence of Saturninus

events.description: The Temple of Portunus is built at the Forum Boarium near the Tiber, dedicated to Portunus, god of keys, doors, and harbors. Its elegant Ionic columns and exceptional preservation make it one of the best-surviving examples of Republican temple architecture. Later converted to a church, which saved it from destruction.
events.name: Temple of Portunus in Rome

events.description: Gaius Marius founds Colonia Mariana on Corsica's east coast, near the mouth of the Golo river. This is one of the first Roman colonies outside mainland Italy, established to settle veterans and consolidate Roman control over the island. The colony grows into a significant town and port, complementing Aleria as a center of Roman civilization on the still partially wild island.
events.name: Foundation of Colonia Mariana

events.description: Tribune Marcus Livius Drusus proposes citizenship for Italian allies who had fought in Rome's wars for generations. When he is murdered and the reforms rejected, the Italian allies revolt. They form their own state 'Italia' with a capital at Corfinium.
events.name: Social War Begins

events.description: To divide the enemy, Rome quickly passed the Lex Julia, offering citizenship to Italians who had not rebelled or had laid down their arms. Behind him is the Law of Plautius-Papiria, where it was enough to simply appear before the praetor. Some Italians believed it, others saw Rome's weakness. However, citizenship for Italians did not grant them political rights, which led to further unrest.
events.name: Italian Citizenship Extended

events.description: Gaius Marius, with the help of the tribune Suspilius Rufus, secured the transfer of command of the war against Mithridates IV from the consul Sulla. Lucius Cornelius Sulla turned his legions back and led them into Rome. This was the first time in the history of Rome that a regular army entered the city, in violation of all the rules. Sulla tracked down and killed Rufus, and declared Gaius Marius a public enemy. Gaius Marius did not expect such a turn of events and fled to Africa.
events.name: Sulla Marches on Rome

events.description: Marius returns to Rome with an army while Sulla fights in the East. He conducts a bloody purge of his enemies, killing senators and equestrians for five days. Heads are displayed on the Rostra. Marius dies 17 days into his unprecedented seventh consulship.
events.name: Marius's Bloody Return

events.description: Sulla captures Athens, which had joined Mithridates of Pontus, after a brutal siege. He sacks the city, massacring civilians and stripping ancient temples of their treasures. Sulla's loot includes Aristotle's library, bringing it to Rome.
events.name: Sulla Sacks Athens

events.description: Sulla defeats Marius's supporters at the Colline Gate outside Rome in a desperate night battle. 50 thousand people die in the battle. Sulla becomes dictator of Rome and publishes the proscription lists‚Äî520 senators and knights are outlawed, their property confiscated, and a bounty placed on their heads. Marius's nephew, Gaius Julius Caesar, was also on the list, but Rome's nobles later convinced Sulla to retain Gaius Julius. The ashes of Gaius Marius were dug up and thrown into the river by order of Sulla.
events.name: Battle of the Colline Gate

events.description: Having become the ruler of Rome, Sulla made efforts to deprive the tribunes of political power (after all, it was the tribunes, in particular, who had started the crisis of recent years): he took away the tribunes' right of veto and the ability to hold political office. All laws must pass through the Senate. Sulla also doubled the number of senators (from 300 to 600) and appointed loyal officers and aristocrats to the Senate.
events.name: Sulla's Constitutional Reforms

events.description: Sulla returned to Rome as a conqueror, taking from the vanquished and handing it over to the victors. He stripped the elites loyal to Gaius Marius of their lands and property and distributed the wealth among his 120,000 legionaries. He formed a militarized "middle class" that owed its wealth personally to Sulla and served as a bulwark against rebels.
events.name: Sulla's loyal soldiers

events.description: Sulla voluntarily resigns his dictatorship after reforming the constitution. He retires to his estate and dies the following year. His epitaph: 'No friend ever served me, and no enemy ever wronged me, whom I have not repaid in full.'
events.name: Sulla Resigns Dictatorship

events.description: Consul Quintus Lutatius Catulus builds the Tabularium on the slope of the Capitoline Hill overlooking the Forum. This massive state archive housed Rome's official records, laws, and treaties inscribed on bronze tablets (tabulae). Its arcaded facade with engaged Doric columns became iconic.
events.name: Tabularium State Archives

events.description: Cicero served as a quaestor in Sicily. He set out to find the scholar's grave, which the Syracusans themselves had already forgotten. He found it in an abandoned cemetery near the Achnadin Gate, overgrown with thorns. The tombstone was carved with a sphere inscribed within a cylinder‚Äîthis was Archimedes's greatest scientific achievement, one of which he was proud. Cicero ordered to clear the grave.
events.name: Cicero searches for Archimedes' tomb

events.description: Spartacus, a Thracian gladiator, escapes from the gladiatorial school in Capua with 70 followers. At this time, Italy was full of slaves, both those captured during Sulla's campaigns and those who appeared in Italy as a result of his reforms. Spartacus's slave army grows to 120,000 and defeats Roman armies. The revolt horrifies Rome‚Äînot just a war against slaves, but a challenge to the entire social order.
events.name: Spartacus Slave Revolt Begins

events.description: Marcus Licinius Crassus defeats Spartacus in Lucania. Spartacus dies fighting, his body never found. Crassus crucifies 6,000 captured slaves along the Via Appia from Capua to Rome ‚Äî bodies left to rot as a warning. Pompey returns from Spain to claim credit for finishing off survivors.
events.name: Death of Spartacus

events.description: Consuls Pompey and Crassus dismantle Sulla's constitution: they restore tribunes' powers, reform the extortion courts, and reopen the censorship. Within a decade of Sulla's death, his careful conservative architecture is demolished.
events.name: Sulla's Laws Dismantled

events.description: The Lex Gabinia grants Pompey unprecedented command over the entire Mediterranean to suppress pirates who had paralyzed trade and even raided the port of Ostia. With 500 ships, he clears the sea in just three months, resettling pirates as farmers.
events.name: Pompey's Pirate Campaign

events.description: The Lex Manilia gives Pompey command against Mithridates of Pontus, despite Senate objections. Cicero supports it in his first political speech. Pompey will spend three years reorganizing the East, creating new provinces and client kingdoms.
events.name: Pompey's Eastern Command

events.description: Lucius Sergius Catilina, a ruined nobleman, plots to overthrow the Republic with an army of debtors and veterans. Consul Cicero exposes the plot in the Senate with his famous orations. Five conspirators are executed without trial ‚Äî controversial even then, and later used against Cicero.
events.name: Catiline Conspiracy

events.description: Pompey captures Jerusalem after a three-month siege, entering the Temple's Holy of Holies ‚Äî but taking nothing. He makes Judaea a Roman client state.
events.name: Pompey Captures Jerusalem

events.description: The patrician Publius Clodius Pulcher was convicted of sacrilege (he entered the women's festival of the Good Goddess in women's clothing), and Cicero destroyed his alibi with his testimony. Clodius harbored a grudge against Cicero.
events.name: The trial of Publius Clodius Pulcher

events.description: Curator viarum Lucius Fabricius builds the Pons Fabricius connecting the Campus Martius to Tiber Island. Constructed of travertine and volcanic tuff with four arches, it is the oldest Roman bridge surviving in its original state. Inscriptions on both sides record Fabricius's name and the bridge's construction.
events.name: Pons Fabricius

events.description: Caesar, Pompey, and Crassus form an informal alliance to overcome the Senate's resistance to pursuing their personal interests. Pompey needs land for veterans, Crassus needs tax contracts, and Caesar needs the consulship and governorship of Gaul to cover his debts. Caesar reconciles old enemies and marries his daughter to Pompey to cement the alliance.
events.name: First Triumvirate Formed

events.description: An unconventional political maneuver, which Pulcher was able to execute with the support of Caesar and Pompey. By law, only plebeians could hold the position of people's tribune with the right of veto. Pulcher went through a complex legal process that resulted in his adoption by a plebeian (younger than himself), after which he received the approval of the College of Pontiffs and Caesar personally.
events.name: The transition of the patrician Pulcher to the plebeians

events.description: Gaius Julius Caesar and Marcus Calpurnius Bibulus, a prot√©g√© of the Senate and Caesar's worst enemy, were appointed consuls. On his first day in office, Caesar proposed to grant land to Pompey's veterans and the poorest citizens from the existing state fund. Facing fierce resistance (especially from Cato and his fellow consul Bibulus), he brought the bill directly to the popular assembly. When Bibulus attempted to veto Caesar's land law, Julius' supporters dumped a basket of manure on Bibulus's head and beat his lictors.
events.name: Lex Agraria

events.description: The tribune Clodius, who had become a plebeian and was granted the office of tribune, used his political power to exile Cicero for executing Catiline's conspirators without trial. Clodius organizes gangs on the streets of Rome, burns down Cicero's estate, and orders the construction of the Temple of Liberty in its place.
events.name: Exile of Cicero by Clodius

events.description: Caesar begins his Gallic Wars. Over nine years he conquers all of Gaul (modern France, Belgium, parts of Germany), conducts two expeditions to Britain, and crosses the Rhine twice. He kills or enslaves over a million Gauls while building a fiercely loyal veteran army.
events.name: Caesar's Gallic Wars Begin

events.description: Clodius became so carried away playing the street king that he began attacking Pompey as well. His gangs blockaded the general's house, and one of Clodius' slaves was even caught with a dagger at the entrance. Pompey supported the tribune Milo, who recruited his gladiators and began driving Clodius's men from the streets; Pompey also supported Cicero's reinstatement, on the condition that he not criticize the triumvirate.
events.name: The Return of Cicero

events.description: The triumvirs meet at Luca to renew their alliance. Pompey and Crassus will be consuls again; Caesar's command extended for five more years. The meeting demonstrates how three men can control the Republic against Senate opposition.
events.name: Conference at Luca

events.description: Caesar lands in Britain with two legions‚Äîthe first Roman invasion of the island. Stormy weather damages his fleet, he encounters fierce British resistance, and quickly withdraws. The news of Caesar's landing there was a bombshell in Rome‚ÄîBritain was considered the end of the world at the time.
events.name: Caesar Invades Britain

events.description: Caesar builds a timber bridge across the Rhine in just ten days ‚Äî a feat of military engineering meant to awe the Germanic tribes. He spends 18 days demonstrating Roman power on German soil, then destroys the bridge to show he could return anytime.
events.name: Caesar Crosses the Rhine

events.description: Julia, daughter of Caesar and wife of Pompey, dies in childbirth. Her death removes the personal bond between her father and husband. The infant also dies. The First Triumvirate begins to unravel.
events.name: Death of Julia and Pompey's son

events.description: Caesar launched a larger invasion: 5 legions and 2,000 cavalry on 800 ships. He advanced inland, crossed the Thames, and forced the British leader Cassivellaunus to pay tribute. After this he had to return, because news came from Rome about his daughter, and rebellions were brewing in Gaul.
events.name: Caesar's second campaign in Britain

events.description: Pompey reinstated the old rule requiring every candidate for the highest office to be present in Rome in person upon application and during the election. This was a move against Caesar, who would be deprived of the opportunity to become consul while in Gaul (and he could not return to Rome, as he could be condemned for his actions during his previous consulship).
events.name: Lex Pompeia de iure magistratuum

events.description: The building burned to the ground during the riots that erupted after the assassination of the politician Publius Clodius Pulcher. An angry mob used the Curia's benches and furniture as fuel for a funeral pyre inside the building, causing the fire.
events.name: Clodius' supporters burn the Curia Hostilia.

events.description: The Gallic chieftain Vercingetorix unites the tribes in a massive revolt against Rome. After initial successes, he is besieged at Alesia where Caesar builds two rings of fortifications ‚Äî one facing in, one facing out against a relief army of 250,000. Vercingetorix surrenders and is later executed in Rome.
events.name: Siege of Alesia

events.description: Clodius is murdered by Milo's gang on the Via Appia. Pompey is appointed sole consul ‚Äî unprecedented ‚Äî to restore order, marking his drift from Caesar toward the Senate.
events.name: Murder of Clodius

events.description: Caesar writes that he is ready to accept the Senate's terms, disband his legions and return to Rome, but only if Pompey does the same. Later he softens the conditions, offering to leave him first two legions, then one and a province, but the Optimates, his opponents in the Senate, are categorically against dialogue with Caesar.
events.name: Caesar proposes disarmament

events.description: Caesar sends his trusted general to Rome ahead of the crisis to defend his political position. Mark Antony is forced to convert from patrician to plebeian status to become a tribune with veto power in the Senate. He also wins election to the College of Augurs with Caesar's financial backing, giving him additional political clout.
events.name: Mark Antony - tribune of the plebs and augur

events.description: Caesar defeats Pompey's forces at Ilerda in Spain without a major battle, maneuvering them into surrender. His famous clemency ‚Äî releasing enemy soldiers rather than killing them ‚Äî wins converts but also spares future enemies.
events.name: Battle of Ilerda

events.description: Caesar seizes the state treasury in the Temple of Saturn despite tribune opposition. He reportedly says the laws go silent in times of war. The treasury contains 15,000 gold bars, 30,000 silver bars, and 30 million sesterces in coin.
events.name: Caesar Seizes the Treasury

events.description: Here, Caesar, marching on Rome, adopted a policy of clemency, releasing the captured senators. He didn't want to look like Sulla, who executed the elites who had betrayed him. This clemency turned public opinion, and cities began to surrender voluntarily.
events.name: Caesar's siege of Corfinium

events.description: Caesar crosses the Rubicon River with the 13th Legion, entering Italy under arms ‚Äî an act of war against the Republic. 'Alea iacta est' (The die is cast), he reportedly says. Pompey and the Senate flee to Greece. Caesar enters Rome without resistance.
events.name: Caesar Crosses the Rubicon

events.description: Caesar was ordered to immediately resign as proconsul of Gaul and disband his legions by a strictly defined deadline. In case of refusal to submit, Caesar was officially declared an enemy of the people and the fatherland. The veto power of the tribunes loyal to Caesar (Mark Antony and Cassius) was ignored - the Senate declared a state of emergency. The tribunes fled, disguised as slaves.
events.name: The Senate's ultimatum to Caesar

events.description: Caesar's veteran legions defeat Pompey's army, twice its size. Caesar guessed Pompey's cavalry attack plan and prepared for it - the Roman aristocratic horsemen were met by a hidden line of infantry with pikes. Furthermore, Caesar's army was significantly more seasoned and disciplined. Pompey lost his fighting spirit and fled the battlefield, after which the soldiers began to surrender.
events.name: Battle of Pharsalus

events.description: Chaos awaited Caesar in Rome. Mark Antony, appointed master of Italy, had failed to govern: the city was mired in street fights over debts, and the elite legions had revolted openly, demanding the promised money and their resignation. Caesar went out alone to the soldiers, announced that he was dismissing them all, and called them citizens. The legionaries, realizing they would never see any trophies, immediately asked to be released.
events.name: Caesar's return to Rome

events.description: Pharnaces II, emboldened by the civil war between Caesar and Pompey, invades Pontus and captures Colchis, Lesser Armenia and part of Cappadocia. He defeats the Roman army at Nicopolis. Caesar defeats Pharnaces II of Pontus at Zela in a matter of hours. He famously reports the victory to Rome with three words: 'Veni, vidi, vici' (I came, I saw, I conquered).
events.name: Veni, Vidi, Vici

events.description: Due to the aggression of Pharnaces of Pontus, Syria was left almost without troops. Caesar stationed an army in Syria, appointed a governor in Antioch, and received several Middle Eastern delegations. Here, Caesar also received a Jewish delegation, thanked them for their assistance in Alexandria, exempted them from taxes, and permitted them to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem.
events.name: Caesar restores order in Syria

events.description: After stabilizing power in the Egyptian province, Caesar and Cleopatra honeymooned. They set off on a cruise up the Nile on Cleopatra's legendary vessel, the Thalamegos (floating palace), accompanied by 400 ships carrying guards and servants, reaching almost as far as Ethiopia.
events.name: The Summer of Caesar and Cleopatra

events.description: Caesar defeats the Pompeian remnants at Thapsus in Africa. Cato the Younger, refusing to live in a world ruled by Caesar, commits suicide at Utica after reading Plato's dialogue on the immortality of the soul. He becomes a martyr for Republican liberty.
events.name: Battle of Thapsus and Death of Cato

events.description: Caesar wins his last battle at Munda in Spain against Pompey's sons. 30,000 Pompeians die in the bloodiest battle of the civil war. 'I have often fought for victory, but today I fought for my life,' Caesar reportedly says.
events.name: Battle of Munda

events.description: Caesar introduces the Julian Calendar, replacing the chaotic Roman calendar that had drifted 80 days out of alignment with the seasons. Based on Egyptian astronomy, it establishes the 365-day year with leap years ‚Äî remaining in use until 1582 when refined by Pope Gregory XIII.
events.name: Julian Calendar Introduced

events.description: Antony's position in Rome was worsened by the forces of Cicero and Octavian. He tried to get his governorship of Gaul passed through the Senate, but the Senate opposed it. Antony set out to fight for Cisalpine Gaul, besieging one of the conspirators, the governor Decimus Brutus, in Mutina.
events.name: Siege of Mutina

events.description: 18-year-old Octavian comes to Antony in his gardens, demanding that he hand over Caesar's money and documents. Antony treats him with disdain, considering him a boy who owes everything to his name. In order to fulfill Caesar's will to distribute sesterces to the citizens, Octavian is forced to sell his property, but in doing so he gained political points.
events.name: Octavian's return to Rome

events.description: A messenger brings Octavius ‚Äã‚Äãinformation about Caesar's death and his last will while he is in the Academy in Apollonia, preparing for the upcoming campaign against Parthia. Despite the pleas of his mother and stepfather to renounce Caesar's will, he prepares and sets out for Italy.
events.name: Octavian ‚Äã‚Äãis informed of Caesar's death.

events.description: Mark Antony delivered his legendary speech at Caesar's funeral in the Roman Forum. There he told about what had happened, showed the people the bloody toga and read the will of the deceased: Caesar left his gardens to the people and gave 300 sesterces to each citizen. Brutus and Cassius were forced to flee Rome because the crowd threatened to tear them apart.
events.name: Caesar's funeral

events.description: Caesar is named Dictator Perpetuo (Dictator in Perpetuity), ending the traditional time limit on the emergency office. He wears a purple toga, sits on a golden throne, and his image appears on coins ‚Äî all unprecedented for a living Roman. Even the allies realize that they are becoming Caesar's servants, not citizens of Rome.
events.name: Caesar Named Dictator for Life

events.description: Cicero's death was one of the key conditions for Mark Antony's entry into the triumvirate. Cicero was caught at his villa in Formiae while attempting to flee to the sea. On Antony's orders, a centurion severed Cicero's head and both hands (with which he wrote his speeches). These trophies were displayed in the Forum in Rome, on the oratorical platform from which Cicero had spoken before.
events.name: The execution of Cicero

events.description: The Triumvirate is recognized as an official state body, standing above the consulate. The triumvirs were granted extraordinary powers for a term of five years. The law gave them the right to appoint magistrates, issue decrees without the consent of the Senate, and dispose of the army and the treasury.
events.name: Lex Titia

events.description: Octavian, Mark Antony, and Lepidus form the Second Triumvirate at a meeting in Lavinium. Antony receives Gaul, Lepidus receives Spain and Narbonne, Octavian receives Africa, Sicily and Sardinia. The triumvirs draw up proscriptions; 300 senators and 2,000 equestrians are to be executed.
events.name: Second Triumvirate and Proscriptions

events.description: The Senate is forced to repeal the decrees declaring Mark Antony and Aemilius Lepidus enemies of the fatherland. Furthermore, the conspirators and assassins of Julius Caesar are now considered enemies of the fatherland.
events.name: Lex Pedia

events.description: Octavian enters Rome 'on bayonets' and initiates the comitia where he is to be elected consul. To ensure the procedure is legal, he nominates his relative Quintus Pedius for the position of second consul, who will simply do as Octavian instructs.
events.name: Octavian is elected consul

events.description: 19-year-old Octavian, like Caesar, leads 8 legions, including the legions of the dead consuls, back to Rome. Two legions, which had hastily arrived from Africa to defend Rome, went over in full force to the side of Caesar's heir upon Octavian's arrival.
events.name: Octavian crosses the Rubicon

events.description: Caesar's loyal officers Hirtius and Pansa assumed the consulship in 43 CE. Despite being Caesareans, they sided with the Senate and Cicero because they considered Antony a usurper. The united army of the consuls and Octavian defeated the army of Mark Antony; Antony was forced to retreat to the Alps with the rest of his army. By coincidence, both new consuls died in battle.
events.name: Mark Antony defeated at Mutina

events.description: Cicero plans to use the young Octavian to overcome Antony's tyranny and pushes through the Senate for preferential treatment for Octavian - introducing him into the Senate (making Octavian equal to the upper echelons), granting him the right to early appointment to office, and the powers of propraetor so that his army would represent the Roman Republic.
events.name: Octavian becomes senator

events.description: At Philippi in Macedonia, the triumvirs Antony and Octavian defeat the Republican forces of Brutus and Cassius. Both conspirators commit suicide. The Republican cause dies with them. Octavian and Mark Antony tacitly agree to divide the provinces: Octavian gets the west, Antony gets the east.
events.name: Battle of Philippi

events.description: Mark Antony's brother Lucius and wife Fulvia revolt against Octavian's actions in Italy because he confiscates their lands to give them to veterans. The rebels were supported by the Senate and briefly captured Rome, but were then forced to withdraw to Perusia. Octavian besieged the city, and by spring the rebels surrendered. Octavian spared Antony's relatives, but ordered the city sacked and burned, and 300 cavalrymen who had sided with Lucius were executed.
events.name: Perusine War

events.description: The Treaty of Brundisium divides the Roman world: Antony gets the East, Octavian the West, Lepidus Africa. Antony marries Octavian's sister Octavia to seal the alliance. The Mediterranean enjoys a brief peace.
events.name: Treaty of Brundisium

events.description: Octavian marries Livia Drusilla of the Claudii, the wife of his opponent in the Perusine War, Tiberius Claudius Nero. For this reason, he divorces his wife Scribonia on the day of his daughter's birth. Livia, meanwhile, is six months pregnant, but this doesn't stop Octavian‚Äîhe will give the offspring to his father. Octavian and Livia will live together for 50 years, sharing the burden of ruling the empire, and finally, Livia's son from her first marriage will become the next emperor.
events.name: Octavian's marriage

events.description: Octavian and Antony meet in Tarentum to extend the triumvirate and provide each other with military assistance: Antony gives Octavian ships to fight Sextus Pompey in Sicily, and Octavian promises Antony legions, as Antony plans a campaign against Parthia (Antony will not receive them actually). Lepidus is not even invited to the meeting.
events.name: Extension of the Second Triumvirate

events.description: Octavian's admiral Marcus Agrippa defeats Sextus Pompeius (Pompey's son) at Naulochus, ending the Sicilian pirate threat that had starved Rome. Lepidus attempts to seize Sicily but his troops defect to Octavian. Stripped of power, Lepidus is exiled as pontifex maximus until death.
events.name: Battle of Naulochus

events.description: Octavian sends a delegation led by his sister to Alexandria to see Antony. Along with Octavia, he delivers money and 2,000 legionaries with equipment. Antony accepts the money and troops, but refuses to see his legal wife, giving Octavian yet another argument that Antony no longer belongs to the Roman nobility and is bewitched by the Egyptian queen.
events.name: Octavia visits Mark Antony

events.description: Octavian ordered the founding of the city of Victory (Nicopolis) on the site of the camp from which he commanded Rome's historic battle against Cleopatra at Actium. On the highest point where Octavian's tent stood, he erected a grand monument adorned with the rostra (prows) of Antony's captured ships.
events.name: The founding of Nicopolis

events.description: The Senate grants Octavian the titles of "Augustus" (Venerable) and "Princeps" and confirms his supreme powers. His position is sacred, his word in the Senate is the first. He controls all military provinces and armies, wields tribunician power, and determines all major policy. The Roman Republic ends in fact; the Empire begins.
events.name: Augustus and the Roman Empire

events.description: Octavian appeared before the Senate and declared that the civil wars were over and that he voluntarily relinquished all emergency powers, returning power to the "Senate and the people of Rome." The senators, terrified by the prospect of renewed anarchy (and having previously been "purged" of Octavian's enemies), began to beg him to stay.
events.name: The Great Abdication of Octavian
